title: universal credit five week wait could be slashed amber rudd hints
story: When asked about whether she would cut the wait for new claimants, the DWP boss said she was looking at what we can do to get cash into peoples hands earlier.It comes after she promised to fix problems with the flagship benefits system and accepted there were areas in which it wasnt working.She told the BBC today that the biggest problem is getting cash into peoples hands as soon as they need it.Advance payments are available for Brits who cant wait five weeks for money, but that has to be paid back immediately out of their first UC sum.Ms Rudd said her department would make it clear to people they can get that upfront as soon as they apply and then pay it back over  months.On a damning report by a UN representative earlier this week, she promised to look at the concerns with women and single mums in particular.But she blasted the findings as being too political and implying the system was there to negatively impact Brits.The aim is to help people when they need it, and help them into work, she told Radio s Today programme.Our motives are to be efficient and compassionate.Ministers have already announced they will give an extra two weeks of several benefits to people on Universal Credit in future - but this wont come in until .At the moment people moving onto the new system get an extra two weeks of just housing benefit to help them cope with the switch.Ms Rudd insisted: The main message I want to give is that Universal Credit is a force for good and we will see how we can fix it.The new benefits system has been beset with issues since it first began being rolled out in .One chippy owner said yesterday the new system was pushing Brits AWAY from work as people couldnt figure out whether they would be better off or not.And earlier this week one desperate mum told how she was forced into sex work to get money for food after waiting for her first payment.One in six Brits still arent getting their first sum on time, the latest Universal Credit stats showed.MANY MPs can’t imagine being truly broke.We don’t mean a bit skint, having to max out the credit card or raid the savings account. We mean having literally no money and going hungry.So it is good to see Amber Rudd, in her first week as Work and Pensions Secretary, consider slashing the five-week wait many claimants endure before their Universal Credit comes through.We support the new benefits system. It is simpler and incentivises work.But that hold-up is unfair and causes real hardship. Sort it, Amber.

title: labour jeremy corbyn power theresa may brexit
story: The Labour leaders right-hand man said the Queen would have a duty to make Mr Corbyn Prime MinisterTheresa Mays Brexit struggles continue.John McDonnell insisted Labour would be able to enter Government even without a mandate from the British public.He pointed to the DUP rebellion this week which has stopped the PM winning key Commons votes on the Budget.The Shadow Chancellor said: The test is whether or not Government is losing consistent votes on the issue of the deal itself.“If it is, it is demonstrating as a minority government it hasn’t got the will of House – a majority in the House.“The normal process is the opposition party should be offered the opportunity to seeit can form a Government.He added: If it’s minority Government and they can’t attain a majority in Parliament, usually it is the duty of the Monarch to make the offer to the opposition the opportunity to form a Government.Speaking at a Reuters event in London Mr McDonnell said Labour wants to see a General Election - but admitted its unlikely without the consent of the Tories.Instead he revealed the partys plan to cobble together a shaky coalition to replace Mrs May in case her deal gets shot down by the Commons.He said: Give us the opportunity to take over and seewe can form a Government, a minority but with a majority position in Parliament.Labour would find it almost impossible to command a majority in the Commons.They would need the support of every smaller party - including the fiercely anti-Corbyn DUP - and all independent MPs.That means the Tories and DUP together will always be able to block Labour from taking power, barring a fresh General Election.Mr Corbyns party faced its own Brexit chaos today as a Labour frontbencher came out in support of a second referendum.Shadow Culture Secretary Steve Reed said: Only the people can break the logjam.

title: michael schumacher footage two months before ski accident
story: The interview footage has been posted on the Formula One legend’s website by his family while updates on his condition remain shrouded in secrecy.The clip was filmed on October , , almost exactly two months before Schumacher suffered a traumatic brain injury after hitting his head on a rock while skiing in the resort of Meribel in the French Alps.Talking about his illustrious career, the German, , who is a seven-time world champion, revealed that he was plagued by self-doubt as a driver.He said: “Records is one thing, doubts, I think it is very important to not be over confident - to be sceptical, to look for improvements.“Yeah, I always felt I am not good enough, I have to work, and that was one part of the recipe that made me what I became.”The most successful F driver ever also said his most memorable victory was his first championship with Ferrari in .He said: “ years no championship with Ferrari, four years myself failing, then finally, in a great race, to achieve it, win the world championship.”Schumacher won his first two championships with the now-defunct team Benneton in  and .He then won five titles in a row with Italian giants Ferrari from  to  cementing his place as an icon of the sport.The German named his greatest rival as Mika Hakkinen who won two championships with McLaren in the late-s.He said: “The most respected guy in all those years was definitely Mika Hakkinen. Great fights, but stable private relationship.”The -year-old also revealed his sporting hero growing up was German goalkeeper Toni Schumacher – who is not related to Michael.Schumacher is being treated at his home in Switzerland surrounded by his family and a team of doctors after ing home in  from Lausanne University Hospital.He was placed in a medically-induced coma following his accident and underwent two operations on his brain.The sporting icon reportedly received £k-a-week care at a special medical facility at his Lake Geneva home, costs which are now expected to have exceeded £m.While updates on his condition from his family have been almost non-existent, his lawyer Felix Damm said in  that Michael “cannot walk.”In August this year,  reports in France emerged alleging that Michael is able to show emotion.Touching comments allegedly from family members of the star suggest he weeps when he sees beautul scenery from his window.The close relatives told magazine Paris Match: When you put him in his wheelchair facing the beautul panorama of the mountains overlooking the lake, Michael sometimes cries.His son Mick, , who Michael was skiing with during the  accident, has admitted he finds it hard to cope with his father’s injures, a friend has said.Nicklas Nin told a Danish news outlet that the teenager, who is also a racing driver, rarely speaks about his famous dad.He said: “Mick does not say he is sad about his father. He just said sometimes that it is sometimes hard.“I still do a little karting with Ralf Schumacherand his team and nobody talks about it .”

title: spinach orange juice dementia
story: Those scoffing the leafy greens which gave cartoon sailor Popeye super strength saw a drop of up to  per cent, a study revealed.Drinking orange too also protected against “poor thinking skills”, reducing risk by up to  per cent, a survey of , men over  years by US university Hard found.Lead researcher Dr Changzheng Yuan said: “Our studies provide further evidence dietary choices can be important to maintain brain health.“One of the most important factors in this study is that we were able to research and track such a large group of men over  years.”Participants ate ying amounts of leafy greens such as spinach, or red and orange veg and fruit.Veg boosted memory power but men eating the most fruit only saw a small protective effect.The best results were for six daily servings.A serving was half a cup of juice, two cups of leafy green and one cup of raw veg or fruit.While veg boosted memory power, men who ate the most fruit each day only saw a small protective effect.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: herbal extract indian plant wrinkles
story: Used in a cream, bakuchiol also lessened uneven skin tones linked to sun exposure.It was more effective than retinol, which is found in many high end cosmetics, and volunteers reported fewer side-effects such as stinging or itching.Bakuchiol is found mainly in the babchi plant and has previously been shown to have antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.Retinol can also be derived from natural ingredients but the one used in anti-ageing cosmetics is often man-made.Researchers from the University of Calornia split volunteers into two groups using bakuchiol or retinol for  weeks.Skin experts found wrinkles shrink by around a fth in both — but more people using bakuchiol saw their skin tone improve. The findings are published in the British Journal of Dermatology.Nina Goad, from the British Association of Dermatologists, called them “promising” but said larger studies were needed.She added: “It is also worth noting that we are talking about subtle changes to the skin. Sadly, no cream can signicantly turn back the clock when it comes to ageing.“Prevention is always better than a cure, and as UV from the sun is a major cause of skin ageing, sun protection can help keep us looking youthful for longer.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: basingstoke christmas lights switch on
story: Revellers at Festival Place shopping centre in Basingstoke, Hampshire, slammed organisers for lighting-up an owl saying there was nothing Christmassy about it.While children from a local primary school were invited to perform in a parade - but it was called off without warning, furious parents claimed.They say their kids, who had been practising a routine, panicked and crying after being abandoned in disused shop - and missing out on the festivities.There was even more disappointment when electronic coloured wristbands given to the crowd for the chance to win £ suffered a technical fault.It resulted in several people, including children, attempting to claim the prize only to be told that they had maled and they were scrapping the competition.People also blasted the annual event for having a light-up owl rather than a Christmas tree, and getting Snow White - played by Strictly star Dani Harmer - to switch it on.After the event on Friday, visitors took to social media to share their experience and vent their fury.James Waine wrote on Facebook: Such a shambles!! Event organisers obviously a bunch of amateurs with no event hosting or planning skills.Would love to see their risk assessments for health and safety. Needs to be an investigation and report of the melee I have just witnessed!Dani Natasha Dacey said: Nothing Christmasay about it! Where the hell was Santa or a bloody Christmas tree   Such a disappointment for the centre.Carly Woodhams added: Worst Christmas switch on ever! I dont think Ive ever seen so many children crying whilst watching lights being switched on!Lauren Heidi Bridgeman said her eight-year-old daughter was in floods of tears after being told her wristband had maled and there was no prize.Laura ONeills daughter was among the school children who didnt get to take part in the promised parade.She said: It was the most disorganised it’s ever been and my daughter was panicked and crying that she wanted to go home.So disappointing for our children to be invited to be part of a parade and taught a dance at school only to get trapped in a disused side room for  mins and then herded like cattle through an awful crowd.She added: It was confusing scary and awful for them and they couldn’t see what was happening.A statement from Festival Place said: “This year’s Festival Place Christmas was planned to have a new focus with a parade event followed by six weeks of fun from the lights switch-on through to  December.“The Winter Woodland launch was incredibly well supported by the local community, but that did make the centre very busy and some planned elements of the parade couldn’t happen – safety is always a priority.“We were most disappointed that the children of Hatch Warren Infant School didn’t get to perform the routine they had worked hard on, and are in touch with the headteacher to see how we can best make it up to them.“Unfortunately there was a technical fault with the wristbands which we couldn’t have foreseen and this meant we regrettably couldn’t launch the competition as planned.Following this we have donated all of the prize money to a local charity, St Michael’s Hospice, our nominated charity.“Festival Place is now decked out for the season, there’s a superb grotto for the little ones and lots more fun to come – we’re really looking forward to welcoming visitors to celebrate all that we have to offer this Christmas.”

title: kidnap schoolgirl van driver cops hunt underpass

title: universal credit man live on pasta gravy mistake
story: Alun Krem-Szczesniak had hundreds of pounds cut from his payments because they wrongly believed he was getting carers allowance.The -year-old, from Pontardawe in Wales, said his experience with the new welfare system has been horrible and he was getting into debt because of errors the DWP made.Alun, who stopped working after contracting glandular fever, is entitled to £ a month, but for two months on the trot a mistake meant he only got half of that - £.The DWP told him it was because he was getting a carers allowance which knocked it down, but he hasnt been claiming that since his father died more than a year ago.He told Wales Online: It has been so humiliating - I have no pride left now. I shouldnt have to be begging people for money or for food.He went on: Friends and family have had to give me money - but I will still have to give them their money back.If it wasnt for them, I would be getting into more and more debt.But there are people that dont have friends or family they can turn to.I was going to my sisters house because I knew that I would have a cooked meal then.I dont think I would be hereit wasnt for the help I have had - I think I would have killed myself, or I would definitely have thought about it.There were times that I felt there was no way out. It has been horrible.Eventually Alun was paid the money he was owed, only for the same mistake to happen again the next month.He claims his landlord has been understanding about his late rent payments, but  bill companies are already chasing him for money.He already owes £ for his water, gas and electricity bills, and cant afford to start thinking about Christmas or even run his car.I have had to prioritise and a roof over my head is my first priority - I cant pay for my utilities at the moment so I dont have any choice but to ignore it, he said.I cant budget for anything - I cant buy any Christmas presents at the moment, it is a case of day to day living.A spokesman for the DWP said: “We have paid Mr Krem-Szczesniak the benefits due to him and we are contacting him to discuss his claim as a matter of urgency.We apologise for any inconvenience caused.”Universal Credit, which replaces six benefits with one, is being rolled out across the country - and will be in every area by the end of the year for new claimants.But its been beset with problems and Brits say its forcing them into debt and they never have any idea how much they will be getting.One single mum said she was forced to take £ for sex work just to make ends meet while she waited for her benefits to come through.The new DWP boss Amber Rudd has vowed to fix problems with the benefit system - and has even hinted she could slash the five week wait for payments.

title: mum mortified flog phone online toilet text blunder

title: welsh coal worker family tree heir wealth
story: Keith Williams, , who lives in a modest bungalow in Carmarthenshire, spent  years toiling in his adoptive fathers coal business.But all the while he has been a member of the Malaysian monarchy and son of the rd Sultan of Perak in Malaysia, named Idris Iskandar Al-Mutawakkil Alallahi Shah.Keith’s mum, Elizabeth Rosa, was  and a trainee nurse at a children’s hospital in Carshalton, Surrey, when she met the royal while he was studying in the UK.They had a fling and she became pregnant.After histo Malaysia, he served as the states rd Sultan of Perak from  until his death from a heart attack in .Keith was adopted as a two-year-old and had no idea about his bloodline , miles away.Keith will never have the chance to meet his father Idris Iskandar Al-Mutawakkil Alallahi Shahafter, who died of a heart attack in A meeting with Elizabeth, his biological mother, in his forties eventually led to the discovery of his fathers incredible status.He said: I was in my late forties when I found my mum and it was a shock really, a bit upsetting. To find out you are the son of a Sultan is just something you wouldn’t expect.“I had jet black hair and darker skin but I had a fantastic upbringing and my adoptive parents told me about my mum when I was .I never imagined I was related to a royal family from the other side of the world.Its like a story from a Disney film andsomeone had told you this story in the cafe or by the bar youd tell them to get out.Malaysia has nine Sultanates and the families live luxurious lestyles in stunning palaces with golden domes.After discovering he had royal blood Keith reached out to members of the family on Facebook, who confirmed they could see the resemblance in the photos but chose not to speak with him.A new palace is now occupied by a Sultan who Keith believes to be his cousin, but the royal relative has refused to engage with him.Keith travelled to Malaysia to visit his father’s mausoleum and the old palace where he once lived – but he was not invited to his cousin’s palace.He thinks the family dont wish to speak with him as they fear he will lay claim to part of their wealth.He told the Mirror: “It is a shame they have decided to close ranks on me. title: leaning pisa tower straight
story: The white marble  metre tower is known around the world - and was famously straightened by Superman in the  movie Superman III.At one point it was feared subsidence would send the historic building crashing to the ground but a series of projects have halted the droop and it is now thought to be reasonably stable.A team of specialists led by professor Nunziante Squeglia, a geotechnics expert at the University of Pisa, have announced the findings after a -year study.He said the tower lost a reported cm of its tilt with its health better than forecast, and added the stability of the bell tower is more than expected.The -year old tower was closed to the public for ten years in the s as part of a £ million restoration project to halt the tilt.Cables were used to secure the monument and the stairs, which offers tourists a breathtaking view of the rolling Tuscan countryside.Since it was built it has survived four major earthquakes and experts say its tilt is now just under four degrees and it is off centre four metres from vertical.Giuseppe Bentivoglio, from the Opera Primaziale organisation that preserves the tower said: It was on the verge of collapse, but we managed to stop the tilt and secure it.Boris Johnson was spotted at the tower in the summer and more than a million people visit the tower every year which is a UNESCO World Heritage Sight.

title: toddler hair vaseline mum flour worse
story: Jaymielee Stewart, , was sent into a blind panic when three-year-old Lucas decided he wanted to style his hair for his first day of nursery - and used a whole tub of the gunk.Frantically looking at ways to get the slippery substance from his locks, she read that talcum powder would work, but as she didnt have any in the house used self-raising flour instead.The Vaseline and flour then combined to form a gooey paste and took hours of scrubbing, combing and washing to get out.It hadnt been a good week as it was, as this greasy gaffe came just a few days after the tot had grabbed some childrens scissors and cut a chunk out of his hair.Jaymielee knew something was wrong when she called Lucas for his breakfast and he was suspiciously quiet.He walked into the kitchen and proudly announced that he had done his hair.At first, she called her mum, Andrena, , who according to Jaymielee just laughed down the phone.She said: “Mum was no good, she was in stitches laughing.She got him in the shower but the water was just dripping back off his face due to the waterproof element of the product.I looked online and it suggested using talcum powder or baby powder, I didn’t have either but was trying to think of something similar.“I knew I had self-raising flour so ran to get it. I tried to rub it in but it just looked like I was baking a cake on his head.“I hoped it would absorb it but it made a paste, it was like the episode with Ross from Friends with the leather trousers.“I rinsed that out and saw someone  had posted about using a deep-cleansing soap. I didn’t have that but I did have soap powder so I stuck about half a box on his head and kept washing it.“In total, I washed his hair  times.“I have used every single bottle of shampoo, two bottles of conditioner, half a bag of self-raising flour, half a box of soap powder and cornflour.“I’ve managed to get most of it out with the shampoo and combing but it’s still very greasy.“I’ll just have to hope it rains on the nursery run so I can get away with him wearing a hat and explain to the nursery teachers what’s happened.“He’ll have to go to nursery looking like a little grease ball.”

story: Ryan Porter got the ITV stars mug on his backside after daring an Instagram-famous tattoo artist to use him as a canvass.But Ryan, , isnt even a fan of Jezza — and only wanted some of genius artist Jord Liddells work on his body.He even plans to somehow sell his tat in the future, saying: If you could take the skin off - especially in a few years - I think it would be worth a fortune.I could be sitting on potential gold dust.Ryan, who got his first tattoo aged , has been branded crazy by pals for getting the Daytime TV legends face on his bum.He added: I like him, but I dont like parts of his show - I think it is public humiliation.Ryans bum tat has now been seen by thousands online after model and tattoo artist Jord posted snaps on social media.He said: I love art and I love the idea of art being on my skin.I have tattoos in my mouth and everything.I have a one in my lip saying bite me and Ive done some myself.Jord had chosen Ryan after joking to his fans that he would give someone a free tattoo of daytime TV legend Jeremy.But space was scarce on Ryans body — meaning he was left with little option but to go for the rump.Jord added: When he said he wanted it on the a***, well I had to it for free!It was a first come first served offer and he was first — but I loved it, and he said I was the only guy he trusted to let me do it.Snaps of the tattoo quickly went viral and now Ryan says he is recognised by strangers.But he is already making plans to add another TV favourite to his bum.He wants to get US shock-show host Jerry Springer on his other cheek.After Jerry, Ryan says he plans on turning his back into a shrine for celebs who have inspired him.Biggie Smalls will be drawn alongside Albert Einstein under the tagline We Are Not Promised Tomorrow.

title: tory mps abandoned may brexit
story: A total of  of the PM’s own MPs had spoken out to indicate they will vote it down next month.And a former minister on her frontbench predicted the true number is now more than , telling The Sun that Mrs May now has “zero chance” of it passing the Commons.Downing Street’s desperate effort to win round sceptical Conservatives Brexiteers as well as Remainers was dealt a fresh blow when Amber Rudd blew apart Mrs May’s claim that voting for her agreement was the only way to avoid no deal.The Work and Pensions Secretary, who only ed to the Cabinet last week, insisted: “The House of Commons will stop no deal. There isn’t a majority for that to take place”.A second Cabinet minister, Treasury chief secretary Liz Truss went on to insist the only choice is actually between the PM’s deal and no Brexit at all.Dubbing the moment as “a historic opportunity to leave the EU”, Ms Truss argued: “If my colleagues don’t sign up to this in Parliament, we’re in grave danger of not leaving at all”.But the PM stuck to her long-running line to tell the Commons that the alternative to her deal “will either be more uncertainty, more ision, or it could risk no Brexit at all”.Three Tory backbenchers thought to be loyal to Mrs May all spoke out to criticise the proposed deal - Neil Parish, Damian Collins and George Freeman.Slamming the deal’s controversial Irish backstop for threatening the UK’s integrity, Tiverton and Honiton MP Mr Parish told Mrs May: “I am a great supporter of yours and I accept what a dficult and tough job you have.“Please can I ask you to listen to these concerns and renegotiate the deal before you put it onto the floor of this House ”Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn leaped on the government chaos to insist Mrs May’s deal was “dead”.But the PM hit back to repeat Mr Corbyn’s weekend gaffe back to him as she reminded MPs that he “hasn’t even read” the draft Brexit deal.Tory ministers have been told by No to expect the ‘meaningful vote’ on her deal to be held on December .Meanwhile Environment Secretary Michael Gove failed to give Eurosceptic MPs firm assurances that Britain will be free of EU quotas by January .Furious Brexiteers demanded he set a red line to ensure any extension of the transition period beyond December  will not apply to fishing.But Mr Gove wouldn’t give a final date for being outside the EU’s Commons Fisheries Policy - only saying Britain would become an “independent coastal state” after the transition period.He urged Eurosceptics: “We need to keep our eyes on the prize of making sure that after that transition period we can have all the opportunities to do the right thing environmentally, economically and socially.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says brexit railways universal credit
story: Two Remainer Cabinet ministers claimed thatMPs reject Theresa May’s deal, Brexit might not happen at all — because a “no deal” exit will somehow be blocked by Parliament.The PM then insisted that, no, the choice WAS no deal or her deal — and Brexit WILL happen next March.Who’s right  It is unmitigated chaos.All of it, plus Downing Street’s blatant betrayal of the DUP, makes the horror of a Corbyn Government more likely. Every Tory should remember that.By far the worst thing that could befall them, and Britain, is not the clean-break Brexit some fear. It is to gt power to a rabble of Marxist oddballs and watch them reduce our booming economy to ash.The surest way to do that being to betray .million Leave voters who, despite everything, largely still trust the Tories to deliver it in some form.Tory Remainers shamefully clamouring for their sore losers’ vote, to reverse the first referendum verdict before it has been enacted, need to wake up.Whatever the result, it would guarantee them electoral oblivion for a decade and unthinkable consequences for Britain.RAIL passengers have suffered a year of the purest hell. A price hike will be a ­disgusting new kick in the teeth.Our trains are a shambles for an advanced economy of our size. There should be no excuse for cancelling ­regular services and advising peak-time commuters “not to travel”.The misery — and the damage to the economy — are immense.To then put fares up . per cent in January, as planned, rubs salt in the wounds. And it plays into the hands of those misguided enough to think nationalisation is the answer.Hard though it is to believe, trains were worse before privatisation.The Government should freeze prices for a year.The train companies need to grasp the anger their incompetence is generating.MANY MPs can’t imagine being truly broke.We don’t mean a bit skint, having to max out the credit card or raid the savings account. We mean having literally no money and going hungry.So it is good to see Amber Rudd, in her first week as Work and Pensions Secretary, consider slashing the five-week wait many claimants endure before their Universal Credit comes through.We support the new benefits system. It is simpler and incentivises work.But that hold-up is unfair and causes real hardship. Sort it, Amber.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: huge boost for theresa may as eu back down on irish border and trade deals
story: The PM, who pulled out of a scheduled appearance on This Morning to prepare for an emergency statement to the Commons this afternoon, has also secured a key concession on trade - in a move that could win her Brexit war in Parliament.Brussels today admitted that technology could be used to solve the thorny issue, using Max Fac solutions at the frontier as part of a future trade deal between the UK and EU.The Prime Minister said on the steps of Downing Street this lunchtime as a historic vote now looms on her deal: The British people want this to be settled. They want a good deal that sets us on course for a brighter future.That is within our grasp and I am determined to deliver it.Now Mrs May will embark on a -hour lobbying operation to convince European leaders they shouldnt veto the agreement at the last minute.As the Brexit deal neared completion:The admission that Britain can trade freely around the world while keeping the Irish border open came in a draft trade agreement between the UK and the EU - and represents a big win for the PM as she battles a Brexiteer rebellion back home.The document released today provides the future framework of a trade deal between the UK and EU, and is expected to be signed off on Sunday alongside the withdrawal agreement published last week.But a number of key issues remain apparently unresolved, with no agreement yet on fishing rights or the status of Gibraltar.And in a worrying sign for Brexiteers, it still states that the final deal will build and improve on the customs union which stops Britain cutting trade agreements around the world.Mrs May hopes that it will provide enough guarantees of future freedom to win over dozens of wavering Tories who are reluctant to back her deal when it comes to the Commons next month.She said today of her deal: I have just updated the Cabinet on progress and will be making statement to the Commons this afternoon.This is the right deal for the UK - it delivers on the result of the referendum and brings back control of our borders, our money and our laws.And it does so while protecting jobs, protecting our security and protecting the integrity of the United Kingdom.Laying out the next steps, Mrs May added: The agreement is between the UK and the European Commission.Hardline Brexit backers were quick to slam the document - Bernard Jenkin said it was far worse than the details revealed last week, while Steve Baker suggested it was an attempt to fool MPs into supporting the PM.On the key question of future customs arrangements, the text says: The Parties envisage making use of all available facilitative arrangements and technologies.It goes on: Such facilitative arrangements and technologies will also be considered in developing any alternative arrangements for ensuring the absence of a hard border on the island of Ireland on a permanent footing.The Sun revealed earlier this week that secret plans were being drawn up in No to win back angry Brexiteers who have threatened to vote down her deal in the House of Commons.Both sides have now agreed on alternative arrangements that can be used to keep the border invisible.A technological solution to the border dilemma, known as maximum facilitation, was initially proposed by former Brexit Secretary David Davis but rejected by Mrs May last summer.The EU previously described it as magical thinking and pushed hard for the backstop which would keep Britain and the EU tied together for years to come.In todays report obtained by The Sun, officials stress the UK will be able to do our own trade deals around the world once we exit the transition period.They say any UK-EU pact will respect the result of the  referendum including with regard to the development of its independent trade policy and the ending of free movement of people between the Union and the UK.But German diplomats are still worried it wont be locked down by tomorrow - and are threatening to boycott the Sunday summitits not.And while the text will reassure eurosceptics on Max Fac, other areas will represent a major headache for the PM.The document contains no references to frictionless trade in goods, as pushed for by Downing Street as a revival of the Chequers plan.Instead it only pledges a trading relationship on goods that is as close as possible, with a view to facilitating the ease of legitimate trade.And it states that Britains new relationship will build and improve on the single customs territory provided for in the Withdrawal Agreement - which will raise fears that the UK will be tied to the bloc for years to come.Negotiators have also laid down the law on so-called Level Playing Field provisions, which will see Britain effectively mirror EU legislation in key areas.When thats signed off, work can FINALLY begin on a trade deal with the EU as we gear up to quit the bloc on March .

title: brexit deal summary highlights key
story: NewsBrexit deal summary: Key points in UK-EU agreement and why Tories are furiousIts the most boring set of documents youll ever read - so weve explained what you really need to know from the Brexit agreementShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporterNicola BartlettPolitical CorrespondentDan Bloom:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video watch-theresa-mays-full-statement-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe UK and EU have finally agreed a Brexit deal - and it could bring down Theresa May. Documents running to  pages are set to be signed off on Sunday  November at a crucial EU summit. But evenits agreed by  EU leaders, the plan could be voted down in the House of Commons. Labour, the DUP and scores of Tory Brexiteers have threatened to defeat the entire pact. If they do, it would throw Brexit back to square one and could topple the Prime Minister. MPs are furious that the deal is too vague and could keep the UK locked under Brussels rules, with no say on making them. So what exactly does the deal say and why are people so het up about it  Weve taken a closer look.  The Brexit deal is in two parts - both of which could provoke a huge backlash. The first is the -page Withdrawal Agreement. This covers the UKs actual exit from the EU, and was agreed on November . The second is the -page Political Declaration on a Future Framework. This covers the shape of a future relationship and was agreed on November . If a deal isnt agreed, the UK will leave the EU on  March  with no deal. This is a No Deal Brexit.  These agreements are only in principle and need to be signed off by three groups. First there was the Cabinet. It agreed the deal but two Cabinet ministers - Dominic Raab and Esther McVey - resigned. Second - the deal needs to be signed off by  EU leaders at a Brussels summit on Sunday  November. Third and last - it needs to be signed off in a vote by MPs in Parliament before Christmas. There is a high risk Theresa May could lose this final vote.  What are the main points and problems in the Brexit deal  Weve looked at each part of the deal and looked at the main elements and sticking points. . The Withdrawal Agreement The transition period can be extended - and we dont know how long for  Weve signed up to a transition period that will continue pretty much all EU rules until December . Now this could be extended - and crucially, we dont yet know how long for. The deal only covers to the year xx. Which to put it mildly is a bit vague. This was then whittled down to , but only later. The transition period can only be extended once. And it would be done by the UK making a request before  June . This request would be considered by an arbitration . That  would have  UK members,  EU members and  independent member, chosen through a legal process. We dont know who theyd be. Eventhe transition period is extended we could still end up in a backstop. For more on that, read on...  Under the backstop - a backup plantheres no agreement for the Northern Ireland border - there COULD be checks on some goods between Northern Ireland and the UK. Theresa Mays DUP allies say this is unacceptable. Northern Ireland firms will access the EU Single Market as a whole without restriction. This will mean Northern Ireland will have to apply EU law on industrial, environmental and agricultural goods. And that means some of these goods would need checks between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK.  The backstop -it kicks in on  January  - will extend EU customs rules across the whole of the UK. This makes Brexiteers furious because it will stop us signing trade deals with the rest of the world - and lock us into Brussels rules without any say on them. Whats worse, we can only quit the backstopthere is mutual agreement between the UK and the EU. Senior UK officials insisted the EU would have to act in good faith. But thatll be cold comfort to Tory Brexiteers. European courts will still have a big hold on the UK  Any judgements from the European Court of Justice handed down during the transition period will be binding on the UK. And the arbitration  that resolves disputeswill not intervene in cases involving EU law. Instead the European Court of Justice will rule on those questions. . The Future Framework Wed need deep co-operation with EU rules  The document promises comprehensive arrangements that will create a free trade area - which sounds like what Theresa May wanted. But it says that will need deep regulatory and customs cooperation. And it calls for common principles in the fields of standardisation, technical regulations, conformity assessment, accreditation, market surveillance, metrology and labelling. Translation: Thats a lot of EU rules were agreeing to follow. Brexiteers are likely to fear this will mean tacking close to EU laws with little freedom to break themwe want good trade. We could have to allow access to our fishing waters  The document commits Britain to establishing a “new fisheries agreement on [among other things], access to waters and quota shares from  January . In other words - it kicks the can down the road. The government says it has defeated EU demands for reciprocal access to UK waters. But Brexiteers fear Britain will have to give up access to its waters to fishing from EU rivals infor a trade deal. Scottish Tory MP Ross Thomson said: “This means sovereignty over our waters sacriced for a trade deal. That is unacceptable. We must be a normal Independent coastal state like Norway.” And Tory Bernard Jenkin said: “It is going to enrage the coastal communities that we have conceded our fishing grounds and quotas.” Scottish Secretary David Mundell, however, threw his weight behind the deal, crushing claims he would resign. Wed stay tied to European courtsThe document the European Court of Justice would still have a role in interpreting EU law when it comes to law enforcement. This is a blow to Brexiteers, who want to quit the jurisdiction of the ECJ. Britain has long promised close co-operation on security - saying its top spooks make that an offer the EU cant refuse. But the document warns: The closer and deeper the partnership the stronger the accompanying obligations. Wed respect Europes human rights laws  The document commits the UK to respect the framework of the European Convention on Human Rights . Right wing Tories hate the convention which protects freedoms such as the prohibition of torture, slavery, the right to a fair trial and freedom of expression. Theresa May considered leaving the ECHR , in  but eventually decided it would not be possible while Brexit was underway. It was understood that she was going to make it a central plank of her re-election plan before calling an early election. But it underpins the Good Friday Agreement. Youll need a visa to go to the EU long-term  Visas wont be needed for short trips to the EU. But the document gives no such guarantee for long-term trips. This was widely expected, but will come as a blow to Remain campaigners . And finally... the whole thing is very vague  Take visas. What does a long-term trip mean  Take customs. What does deep co-operation mean  And more. Theres lots of very positive language but it kicks many cans down the road. Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon warned the document was full of unicorns and adds up to a blindfold Brexit. Furious Mark Francois, of the Tory Brexiteer battalion, branded the deal a fig leaf that is not legally binding and wont fool anybody. He told the BBC: It is  pages of political camouflage designed to take peoples eye off the withdrawal agreement and persuade them to vote it through. It will not work. Theresa May has a Brexit deal, but the danger is looming that it will be defeated in the House of Commons. Even getting it past her Cabinet forced Esther McVey and Dominic Raab to resign. Now she faces two more hurdles - an EU summit with  leaders on November , and then the vote in Parliament at some point before Christmas. MPs are grouped in several factions - their warring opinions are explained more fully here. But or more vote against the deal, they will defeat the deal. Against the deal TORY BREXITEERS: There are up to  , led by Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees-Mogg. They will vote down a deal that keeps Britain trapped in vassalage with Brussels. TORY HARD REMAINERS: Only about a dozen, but many - including Justine Greening and Jo Johnson - will vote against, instead wanting a second referendum. DUP: Theresa Mays Northern Irish allies - who she handed pound.bn - are -strong. They will vote down the dealit allows customs checks between Ulster and Britain. LABOUR LOYALISTS: About  MPs are consistently loyal to Jeremy Corbyn on Brexit. The party has confirmed theyll be told to vote against the deal because it doesnt meet Labours six tests. LABOUR REMAINERS: There are about  hard Remainer Labour MPs. Theyre likely to oppose the deal to avoid enabling a Brexit.OTHERS: The SNP , Lib Dems , Plaid Cymruand Greensare all likely to vote against. For the deal TORY LOYALISTS: Well over  are likely to vote with Theresa May, for the deal. Many have paid government jobs - so would have to quitthey oppose her. NERVOUS LABOUR: Some Labour MPs could BACK a deal - fearing otherwise Britain will be plunged into an even worse No Deal. There could be  or more. Caroline Flint is among them. UnknownLABOUR BREXITEERS: There are only about half a dozen. It was generally thought theyd side with Theresa May, but Kate Hoey MP broke ranks and said she could vote against.

title: brexit timetable what happens next
story: NewsBrexit timetable: What happens next now UK finally has a deal with the EU The UK faces a frenetic few weeks in a countdown that could topple Theresa May from power. Heres what happens next, key dates and whether Brexit can be stoppedShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsShe has to overcome three hurdles - her Cabinet,  EU leaders, and a vote in the House of Commons"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe UK finally has a draft Brexit deal with the EU, but Theresa May isnt out of the woods yet. She has to overcome two more major hurdles -  EU leaders at a summit on November , and finally a vote in the House of Commons. At both stages she could be thwarted - especially the last one. MPs are threatening mutiny over the Northern Ireland backstop, a customs backup plan that could leave the UK trapped in Brussels orbit. A lot is unknown, but here is the most likely timetable in the weeks and months ahead. Tuesday  November : After months of stalled talks over the Northern Irish border, and  days after the Brexit vote, a deal was finally reached at a technical level between the UK and EU. Wednesday  November: Ministers flooded to an emergency Cabinet meeting from pm that ran for more than four hours to sign off the deal. This was the first of three danger moments for the PM, and ministers were ordered to either back the deal or quit. Thursday  November: Cabinet ministers Esther McVey and Dominic Raab both resigned over the Brexit deal as Mrs May gave a statement to Parliament defending it. At the same time key Brexiteers launched a challenge to her leadership, forcing Mrs May into a defiant statement in Downing Street. Thursday  November: It emerged the second part of the deal - a political declaration on the future relationship - had been reached.  Sunday  November: An emergency EU summit with  other leaders in Brussels to sign off the deal. This will be danger moment number two for the Prime Minister, when she has to face down pro-EU leaders like Emmanuel Macron and Angela Merkel - and Spain, who threatened to block the deal over Gibraltar. Early December  A vote in the House of Commons on the deal. This is danger moment number three for Theresa May - and by far the worst. If the deal is voted down she will almost certainly have to resign or face a vote of no confidence. She claims the UK will leave with No Deal anywayshe loses. But Labour say she should be forced back to the negotiating table - see below. Theresa May has a Brexit deal, but the danger is looming that it will be defeated in the House of Commons. Even getting it past her Cabinet forced Esther McVey and Dominic Raab to resign. Now she faces two more hurdles - an EU summit with  leaders on November , and then the vote in Parliament at some point before Christmas. MPs are grouped in several factions - their warring opinions are explained more fully here. But or more vote against the deal, they will defeat the deal. Against the deal TORY BREXITEERS: There are up to  , led by Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees-Mogg. They will vote down a deal that keeps Britain trapped in vassalage with Brussels. TORY HARD REMAINERS: Only about a dozen, but many - including Justine Greening and Jo Johnson - will vote against, instead wanting a second referendum. DUP: Theresa Mays Northern Irish allies - who she handed pound.bn - are -strong. They will vote down the dealit allows customs checks between Ulster and Britain. LABOUR LOYALISTS: About  MPs are consistently loyal to Jeremy Corbyn on Brexit. The party has confirmed theyll be told to vote against the deal because it doesnt meet Labours six tests. LABOUR REMAINERS: There are about  hard Remainer Labour MPs. Theyre likely to oppose the deal to avoid enabling a Brexit.OTHERS: The SNP , Lib Dems , Plaid Cymruand Greensare all likely to vote against. For the deal TORY LOYALISTS: Well over  are likely to vote with Theresa May, for the deal. Many have paid government jobs - so would have to quitthey oppose her. NERVOUS LABOUR: Some Labour MPs could BACK a deal - fearing otherwise Britain will be plunged into an even worse No Deal. There could be  or more. Caroline Flint is among them. UnknownLABOUR BREXITEERS: There are only about half a dozen. It was generally thought theyd side with Theresa May, but Kate Hoey MP broke ranks and said she could vote against. Thursday  December: The last chance EU Council summit. If the deal is rejected in the House of Commons, Theresa May could be forced to renegotiate parts of it with the other  EU leaders at this get-together in Brussels. Thursday  December: Parliament rises for its Christmas break. Unless MPs are recalled to Parliament - an incredibly rare move - this is the last chance to approve the Brexit deal in a second meaningful vote. If its rejected a second time, that really could be curtains for the PM. Labour say there should be a general election orthat fails, even a second EU referendum. The EU has agreed a two-part Brexit deal - and it has enraged Tories. Here are some of the reasons why:The transition period can be extended - and we dont know how long for Goods face being checked between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK We need the EUs permission to quit the backstop European courts will still have a big hold on the UK Wed need deep co-operation with EU rules We could have to allow access to our fishing waters And finally... the whole thing is very vagueFOR THE FULL GUIDE CLICK HERE January to March : Dozens of national and regional parliaments across the EU will hold their own votes on the Brexit deal. Meanwhile, No Deal planning has to ramp up in case everything doesnt come together in time.  March : Brexit Day. If theres a deal, this will be a total anticlimax because a transition will be in place. If theres No Deal, planes could be grounded, ports jammed up and customs checks thrown into chaos at pm.   December : Transition ends. If theres a deal, this is when the transition period - which continues pretty much all the EU rules we have now - is supposed to end. Only at this point will the much-discussed Brexit deal actually kick in. But this date could be extended .  January : Backstop kicks in. If theres still no deal to stop customs checks on the Northern Ireland border, under current plans a backstop would kick in. This could keep the UK tied to EU customs rules, until a proper agreement is reached, in exchange for keeping the Northern Ireland border open. June : The next scheduled general election. Amazingly, the transition period -it gets extended - could still be going on at this point.  December : The transition period might finally end. What happensa deal is voted down   If MPs do not vote for the PM’s deal, she says the UK defaults to a no-deal Brexit. Such a scenario could trigger a crisis in the financial markets, plummeting sterling and adding to an unprecedented political crisis. But she also says it could result in no Brexit at all. Thats a cryptic way of saying she could be forced to:Renegotiate the deal Resign from office Hold a general election Hold a second EU referendumTheresa May has a Brexit deal, but the danger is looming that it will be defeated in the House of Commons. LABOUR REMAINERS: There are about  hard Remainer Labour MPs. For the deal TORY LOYALISTS: Well over  are likely to vote with Theresa May, for the deal. Many have paid government jobs - so would have to quitthey oppose her. UnknownLABOUR BREXITEERS: There are only about half a dozen. It was generally thought theyd side with Theresa May, but Kate Hoey MP broke ranks and said she could vote against. What would happen immediatelythe deal is voted down  Constitutionally, the Government must decide what happens next. Ministers have to come to Parliament by  January to make a statement setting out their proposals. Will the PM quit or face a leadership challengeshe loses the vote   Few Tory MPs seem happy with Mrs May’s leadership but important factors have somehow managed to keep her in power to date, and they haven’t changed. Tory MPs know they are likely to face voters’ anger and there is no agreed successor. If she resigns it could still be messy. Will there be an election  It doesnt happen automatically. There are two dferent ways it can happen under the law. . Theresa May loses a vote of confidence in the Commons - by a simple majority . If that happens, convention suggests she must resign and nominate a new PM. That PM has  days to win enough support. If they cant, the new PM must then hold a general election. . MPs vote directly for a new election. This vote, however, would have to pass with a two-thirds majority of all MPs. Can Brexit be stopped   Some argue the only real deadline for a deal is  March . As long as a deal has been struck, and approved by Parliament in a meaningful vote by Brexit day, then Article  can be extended in order for the legislation to be passed. This could mean that evena deal was voted down the first time round it could be put in front of MPs again, possibly early next year. Meanwhile, campaigners are calling for a second EU referendum that could cancel Article  altogether. If it did happen, this would probably need Article  to be extended as well. AND FINALLY... heres all that in the form of a barmy flow chart  Disclaimer: Labour still hasnt guaranteed it could back a second referendum, and with such chaos over Brexit, no one can quite predict what will happen!

title: dozens been wrongly refused visas
story: NewsDozens may have been wrongly refused visas in Home Office blunderCampaigners claimed hundreds of highly skilled workers were being removed because of minor tax discrepanciesShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsCaroline Nokes apologised for the error "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDozens of people may have been wrongly refused visas as part of a Home Office blunder. The government carried out a review after campaigners claimed that hundreds of highly skilled workers were facing removal due to minor discrepancies between immigration paperwork sent to the Home Office and tax information given to HMRC. Ministers insisted the majority of those refused entry under Tier visas were not because of minor tax errors but were instead attempts to misrepresent self-employed earnings to be given leave to stay in the UK. The government also faced criticism for refusing entry based on paragraph  where an applicant’s character and conduct call into question their desirability of remaining in the UK. The review found that at least people may have been affected. As well as cases which have already been allowed by the courts and tribunals, the review has identied  decisions the government will overturn. There are a further  cases where the Home Office needs more information before reconsidering their cases.   The Home Office say they will contact each of the  iniduals concerned to resolve their cases by the end of December. Immigration minister Caroline Nokes said in a statement: Errors of this kind are always regrettable, and I do not seek to minimise the impact that the error may have had on the iniduals concerned.I will also ensure that the findings in this small minority of cases are used to inform our future decision making, to ensure that similar errors are not repeated. Skilled migrants make an important contribution to our economic wellbeing and our society. The Government recognises the need to attract and retain them, and our immigration system will continue to do so. However, it is important that people play by the rules to preserve the integrity of the immigration system. The governments review examined , applications refused since January . The discrepancies between the earnings declared to the Home Office and those shown by their tax records were over pound, in % of cases , according to the review. Tier was aimed at highly skilled migrants, who were able to take up employment or self-employment in the UK without having a sponsor and is no longer open.

title: bullied girl 12 inquest halted
story: NewsBullied girl, , inquest halted after phone call from worried parentA coroner had been expected to deliver a verdict into the death of bullied schoolgirl Jessica Scatterson, from WarringtonShareByLuke Traynor:,  NOV NewsJessica Scatterson died in April last year "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn inquest into the death of a schoolgirl has been dramatically halted following an unexpected phone call from a member of the public. A coroner had been set to deliver a verdict following the death of -year-old Jessica Scatterson, who was found dead in her bedroom in Bewsey, near Warrington. The tragedy happened in April last year after allegations that she had been bullied at her school, Penketh High in Warrington. Jessica had previously self-harmed, her pals said, and left suicide notes, the Liverpool Echo reports. Proceedings were stopped after an unexpected phone call from a member of the public. He had seen media reports about the case, and telephoned the Warrington Coroners Office yesterday to claim his two daughters moved to a dferent school after problems with bullying some years ago.   The man, whose identity was not disclosed, claimed there were systematic failings at Penketh High which was only tolerated by his eldest daughter until her GCSE year after which she left the school. He had written to the Department for Education in October  to voice his fears, which pre-dated Jessicas death, and had received an email reply back from the government department, Alan Moore, the senior coroner for Cheshire, said. The sudden interruption led to furious scenes at Warrington Town Hall, with dad Chris Scatterson believing the correspondence needed further investigation and a halt to the inquest.   But Jessicas upset mother, Rachel Dawber, demanded the enquiry continue. Mr Scatterson told the coroner: My feelings on it is, are the school covering it [bullying] up  I think this is relevant. A relative, and supporter of the dad, added: I feel that its relevant to Jessicas case and maybe her state of mind. It seems as though the way she reacted to some of these messages....that affected her state of mind.   Coroner Moore replied: I must make some further enquiries...well obtain a statement from the gentleman concerned, and Ill have a statement from the principal at the school... I completely sympathise with Ms Dawber, but my job here is to investigate fully, fairly, and fearlessly on anything that might have had a bearing on her death. Im so sorry, I had no idea this gentleman would approach us, but it would be utterly inappropriate for me not to share that with you. Im so sorry about that.  Earlier this morning, Penketh High headteacher John Carlin had told the inquest that, since Jessicas death, he had implemented new policies on bullying and self harm at the school, and had employed an emotional well-being coordinator. The inquest heard how Jessica had spoken to teachers about her dficult home le, and unpleasant messages between her and her friends were discovered on her social media accounts. The -year-olds pals had told police that she had previously self-harmed, and officers said they had become aware of an incident ‘relating to Jessica being bullied at school’ in April . Jessica had come home with scratches to her face and a swollen eye after arguing with another girl. The matter was reported to the police but it was unclear who had started the fight so no action was taken. If you need to speak to someone, Samaritans are available   by calling   or by emailing jo@samaritans.org

title: one worded text terrified mum
story: NewsOne-worded text that terried mum into thinking her newborn baby had diedSarah McGuiness, gave birth to her son Max Williams at just  weeks after going into early labourShareCommentsByMark SmithAbigail OLeary:,  NOV NewsSarah said she lived in constant anxiety about losing Max"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA one-worded text terried a mum into thinking her premature, newborn baby had died. Sarah McGuiness gave birth to her son Max Williams at just  weeks after going into early labour. Despite medics best efforts to slow down the pregnancy, Max was born breathing, but weighed just lb and oz. Sarah, from Llanwit Major in South Wales, said she lived in constant fear her fragile son wouldnt survive - and one night was terried she had lost him forever. While staying at the University Hospital of Wales, Sarah had been getting some sleep on the ward while her partner Chris sat at Maxs incubator in the intensive care baby unit. After checking her phone one last time before going to sleep, she saw the words RUN pop up on the screen in a text from Chris, reports Wales Online. Max had stopped breathing after something became trapped in his airways. Despite being revived, he stopped breathing three more times that night before one one occasion all alarms were set off and a crash team came in to work on him. Sarah and Chris watched on in disbelief as the team worked to save their newborn sons le.  Describing the horric moment they thought theyd lose Max, Sarah said: I’ve never moved as quickly as I did that night. “It usually takes a while to get buzzed through the doors of the women’s unit, but someone must have seen how I was running because they opened straight away. “When I arrived, there was a team working on Max. Something had got stuck in his airway and he’d stopped breathing. “They managed to revive him but it happened three more times, once when I was holding him and he just turned blue in my hands. “Suddenly all the alarms were going off and the crash team rushed in. We were left standing in the corner of the room feeling a terror that’s hard to describe. “I don’t think that memory of being on the brink of losing everything but being unable to change any of it will ever leave us. Sarah had been having a normal pregnancy up until the morning of her -week scan, when she realised she was bleeding. A midwe referred her straight to the Princess of Wales Hospital in Bridgend where tests revealed she was in early labour. She was given injections to try and slow down labour, medication to help mature the baby’s brain and lungs and was told she might deliver before the end of the day.   In the space of just a few short hours, Sarah and partner Chris Williams lives changed forever. Sarah said: “I started shaking uncontrollably at that point, out of shock I think more than anything. “And it was then that the midwe whispered words in to my ear that I think helped to save all three of us in the days that were to come. “She hugged me really tight and told me that I couldn’t cry now. She said that my stress and adrenaline could speed up labour and my job was to stay as calm as possible. “In a situation that was suddenly and very dramatically out of our control, it gave me a focus.” The pair were rushed to the University Hospital of Wales where they were prepared for the imminent birth of their baby. But the medication to slow the labour seemed to work, giving them hope that the pregnancy might progress for another few weeks at least. The following morning, Sarah woke up in a pool of blood and was convinced that she’d lost the baby. An examination revealed that she was cm dilated. The baby was still alive but she was now in full labour. Sarah added: “From then on we were on one major countdown. We knew that every minute the baby stayed inside would help so we celebrated each hour that passed. “But the pain got worse as the days progressed, and we knew that there was no stopping the inevitable.   “I was told to push when I was ready and I remember Chis saying ‘whatever happens next, our baby is about to be born’. In that moment we felt so happy.” Baby Max was born tiny but breathing, although it took some time for the neonatal team to get all the necessary tubes into him. Chris and Sarah said they couldn’t see Max from where they sitting, so they avidly watched everyone’s expressions for signs that he was okay. Eventually, and to their complete surprise, they were given the opportunity to hold their new son. Sarah said in those few seconds they felt immense pride and a confidence that Max would survive. For the first few weeks, Sarah and Chris quickly learnt to adapt to the routine of le on the neonatal ward with their new son. For  precious seconds twice a day, the new parents took it in turns to hold him through the incubator windows while his sheets were being changed. They celebrated each tiny bit of progress and laughed at how he would suck avidly at the cotton bud dipped in Sarah’s milk, which they used to keep his mouth clean and moist.   But at around the two-week mark things began to change - and Max began to struggle with his breathing on the night Sarah received the dreaded text. With Max’s condition continuing to deteriorate, a decision was made to start him on a course of steroids. It was the only option left open, but given the very long and frightening list of potential side-effects – including partial but permanent paralysis – it was a very frightening thing for Chris and Sarah to consent to. Max was paralysed and sedated and placed on an oscillator breathing machine to keep his lungs permanently inflated while the medication took effect. Sarah and Chris were painfully aware that the longer he was dependent on the machinery to breathe for him, the worse his chances for a normal le were going to be. Thankfully the steroids did their job and, very slowly, Max’s condition started to improve. Each day, the consultants would make the smallest adjustment, trying to work out the best course of action for Max. Sarah added: “Each baby and each situation is very dferent and there are so many components in the care of a neonatal baby.   “I have so much respect for the medical team who painstakingly and meticulously took the tiniest of calculated risks every day to work out what was best for Max. “That takes real bravery and determination.” Eventually, Max was well enough to come off the ventilator and be moved out of intensive care on to the high dependency unit . But even though the family were one step closer to home, some of their darkest days were yet to come. Shortly after moving on to HDU Max was diagnosed with stage  retinopathy of prematurity , an eye condition that can cause blindness in premature babies. Sarah and Chris were told that to be in with a chance of saving Max’s sight, he would need laser eye surgery under anaesthetic. This would mean ato the ventilator and the intensive care unit. Sarah said: “The thought of going back to the place that filled us with such dficult memories terried us, but the fear I felt at the prospect of Max being blind just grabbed hold of me and wouldn’t let go. “Through the whole journey I’d comforted myself by daydreaming about all the tiny normal things we could do together in the future, like walking down the street jumping in puddles. “Now even that seemed like it was being taken away.” Still a full month away from his official due date, Max was taken to theatre for surgery. He spent two days on the ventilator before ing to HDU. Then came the wait to find out whether the surgery had been a success.   During this time Max was also having dficulty learning to swallow and would often choke and stop breathing for periods of time. Eventually, despite his setbacks, Max was finally well enough to go home – a week after his official due date – and his parents received the news that his eye surgery had been a success. Max required home oxygen and some feeding support for a few months after “graduating” from the hospital. Sarah said she’d expected the mixture of fear and excitement she felt on the day they finally went home. What she hadn’t expected was the sadness at having to say goodbye to the neonatal team. “We developed such a strong bond with so many special nurses and consultants who’d cared for Max that it was dficult to leave them behind,” she said. “They’d got us through the hardest possible of times by showing care, compassion and even humour at times. “We’ll never forget these nurses and all the staff. We wouldn’t be a family today without them.”

title: young woman made feel insecure
story: NewsYoung woman made to feel insecure by Facebook trolls killed herselfJade Turner, of Bolton, Greater Manchester, sent tragic text messages to her mother before taking her own leShareCommentsByHayley SewellChris kitching:,  NOV NewsJade Turner had talked openly about taking her own le, an inquest heard "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young woman took her own le after she became insecure and worried about her appearance when she fell victim to Facebook trolls, an inquest heard. Jade Turner, , built a large following on her social media page but had few friends and a boyfriend who became violent and sent a picture of him with another woman in bed, leaving her destroyed. The catering assistant openly spoke about taking her own le and even suggested she would go to the Dignitas clinic in Switzerland to die by assisted suicide. Miss Turner, from Bolton, Greater Manchester, had sent messages to her mother reading I love you mum and I‘m sorry before she suffered an overdose on July . She was later found dead in her flat - where she had a book on suicide in her bedroom - after her father raised the alarm, the inquest was told.  The hearing was told Miss Turner had been diagnosed with Aspergers and autism aged  and had enrolled on a Living with Autism course. But she was said to have hated her condition and often isolated herself and she did not have many friends whilst having a large presence of , followers on Facebook. Her mother, Lesley Robinson, told the Bolton hearing: “After the diagnosis the depression she suffered with got worse. She always wanted to be on her own. She had a relationship with a boy and that ended and then met someone called Anthony and moved in with him for six months.  “She seemed happy at first but then there were problems with the relationship and Jade moved in with me. She wanted to be independent and joined a separate living group - she had to leave after  months and moved into a flat. “She saw it as a new adventure. One of her many problems was Facebook. She got a lot of trolls and got into Facebook relationships with boys. She met people she knew on Facebook in real le but she became concerned about her appearance and felt insecure. The last boyfriend became violent and sent a picture of him with another woman in bed and this destroyed her. This badly affected her and broke down their relationship. Her depression became worse. Nothing could change her mind and she had thought she would end her own le.  Miss Turners mother added: “We would sit together and talk about how she felt but nothing to change her mind set. She hated her condition and said she was stuck with it for le. “One Saturday th we met up and had coffee. She sent me a message later and I said ‘stay strong’. Nothing was dferent that day. “I had a message from her saying ‘I love you mum’ and ‘I‘m sorry’ at about pm. On Sunday I had a text from her father saying he couldn’t get hold of her. She had never done any harm to herself before. She didn’t have many friends, she just had people on Facebook.” Jades father, Mark Turner, said: “When she didn’t want to speak to me she would ignore calls and texts then speak to me later.  “She then sent me a text saying she was going to end her le. She even mentioned going to Switzerland to end her le by euthanasia. I was not aware that she did anything to hurt herself. “She would get down and said her condition was getting her down. She couldn’t hold down a job and found it hard to find a job. “She felt lonely and would come over sometimes but would always go home, she would never stay. She didn’t have many friends, she spoke to a few neighbours but she always wanted to move and wasn’t happy there. “I saw her on the th July and she came for tea and she seemed normal. She was quiet and glued to her phone.  “She was always on her phone and kept it very private. She didn’t make much conversation. She went to Blackpool on st July as she wasn’t working at the time. She went to Blackpool on her own and got a hotel room and just cried. “She liked the hotel as her last boyfriend had taken her there before and she said she just wanted to get away from Bolton for a weekend. I tried to contact her and get her counselling sessions but she said they wouldn’t help. “A text message to me said she didn’t want to be here anymore and she had already planned the day and everything. She said ‘I have made my mind up’. I asked her to try and tried to persuade her. On the th she sent me a message which said she wanted to end her le and would take a cocktail of drugs on Friday.  “I got a text from her on th saying ‘I love you’ with kisses. I tried contacting her on th and had no reply. “When I was at the flat there was no response so I called the police and feared the worst. Mr Turner told how his daughter was found collapsed and the police showed him a note she had left. Police found a book on suicide in her bedroom and she left notes in her phone to inidual family members. Jodie Wood, senior mental health practitioner, said: “I saw her on th July for an initial assessment. She was experiencing low mood following her relationship breakdown.  She expressed she was searching for ways to end her le but had no intention to do this. She said she became obsessed with this and said it was down to her autism. “I recommended her for a Living with Autism course and referred her for CBT. She said she had no intention to complete the act and that she had future plans. She was scared of dying. Coroner Alan Walsh recorded a conclusion of suicide and said: “I am satisfied she had a number of complexities. She had a number of relationships of which none were sustained. Some were bad for her and had a bad effect on her. “She had continuous support from her mother and father. There were times where she isolated herself. You as parents could not have done any more to help her. She was someone who suggested she was going to harm herself and end her le. She gave details as to when it was going to happen and she was quite articulate, and she told people and made notes with an articulate mind. “She was a very attractive lady and it is very sad she had to live with autism and what it must have been like for her.” Whatever youre going through, the Samaritans are there to listen any time, free from any phone on  . They are there round the clock,  hours a day,  days a year. For more information on how they can help, visit their website here .
